Advice:
For travellers:
• Defer all non-essential travel due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.
For those in country:
• Monitor this alert.
• Follow the advice and requirements of local authorities
• Closely monitor the extent of transmission in your location.
• Keep yourself in the best possible health. Get the recommended amount of sleep each
day, eat a healthy diet, and keep up regular physical activity.
• Limit face-to-face contact with others, stay home as much as practically possible.
• Practice social distancing: Keep 2 metres (6 feet) away from other people. Consider
whether gatherings with friends and family should be minimised. Avoid large and small
gatherings in public. Avoid crowds.
• Wear a mask whenever required to. Wear a mask when in public, especially if it is not
possible to keep 2 metres (6 feet) away from others.
• Cough and sneeze into your elbow, not your hands.
• Do not shake hands, hug or kiss.
• Wash your hands frequently. Carry hand sanitiser for use when soap and water are not
readily available.
• Avoid sharing food, drinks and personal items.
• Avoid touching your face. If you must touch objects which are handled by many people
(such as handrails, doorknobs) ensure you do not touch your face. Wash your hands /
clean them with hand sanitiser soon as possible.
For those who have any symptoms:
• Stay at home and do not have contact with others. Call for medical advice. Follow the
local procedure for your area for getting tested.
• It is likely that mild cases will remain at home, in isolation from others, for the duration
of the illness.
• If seeking in-person medical care, wear a mask. Use private transport and avoid
contact with others as much as possible.
• Do not travel if you are sick.
Info: Papua New Guinea: COVID-19 outbreak

Advice:
Inbound travellers
• Essential travel to Papua New Guinea can resume with stringent precautions ,factoring
intheeffectsoftheCOVID-19pandemic.Thisassessmentismadejointlybyour health
and security professionals.
Managers
• Continue to maintain your international staff in two groups for planning purposes:
o Essential staff who are prepared to remain in an environment of reduced health
capabilities and increased mobility restrictions. This group should implement
their stand-fast plan and adopt flexible working arrangements, where possible.
o Non-essential staff and their dependants in Papua New Guinea, as well as
dependants of essential staff, whom you will prioritise for outbound travel in
case the operational risk environment deteriorates.
• Closely monitor developments for any further announcements by the authorities,
including the imposition of additional mobility restrictions by the National Control Centre
for COVID-19 and changes to restrictions on flights to international destinations.
• Revise your Business Continuity Plans (BCP) and ensure they are implemented.
• For the entire workforce, including local staff, ensure strict compliance with National
Control Centre restrictions.
In-country workforce
• Abide by all official directives. People currently in Papua New Guinea should consider
organisation- specific requirements. Ensure you have provisions in place at your
accommodation and work sites for at least two weeks.
• If you decide to depart, reconfirm your flight itinerary with the relevant airline.We do not
hold information on specific flights. Allow additional time for all journeys to account for
potential screening measures at ports of arrival and departure.
• If you plan to remain in Papua New Guinea, review your visa status to avoid any
financial and legal repercussions.
• Closely monitor developments, including any announcements pertaining to internal
travel restrictions and protests against such measures.
• For any additional queries or more itinerary- specific health and travel advice, call
International SOS.
Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. People who are sick face the risk of being tested and
quarantined. Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like
symptoms, following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three-to-six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.
ASSISTANCE
Info:
Papua New Guinea: Evacuation level reduced to STAND BY due
to improved inbound, outbound mobility options

(Insignificant Risk)
People in Aalborg (North Denmark region) on 8 May should plan journeys bypassing a
protest against COVID-19-related restrictions due to the risk of localised unrest.
Supporters of the ‘Men in Black’ activist group will gather at 19.00 (local time) at
Kildeparken and march towards Gammeltorv. Previous such gatherings have resulted in
localised scuffles between participants and the police.
ASSESSMENT
• Plan journeys bypassing the protest as a precaution and to minimise travel delays.
• If travelling near the affected area, reconfirm the status of routes before setting out and
allow additional time for journeys.
• Anticipate an increased police presence around the demonstration. Follow official
directives, including COVID-19-related measures.
• Leave an area at the first sign of unrest, or if a crowd is forming.
• Monitor our Denmark alerts for updates.
Info:
Denmark: Aalborg (North Denmark region): Plan journeys
bypassing protest on 8 May

Advice:
Do the following:
• Select safe food and pay attention to hygiene:
o Wash fruits and vegetables prior to consumption.
o Choose food that has been thoroughly cooked.
o Wash your hands thoroughly before eating.
o When preparing food, ensure that raw and cooked foods are separated. Don't
use the same utensils for raw and cooked food unless washed in between.
• Seek medical advice if symptoms develop.
Info: Sweden: Cases of Salmonella under investigation

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Essential travel to Iraq may be possible subject to an itinerary- and profile-specific
review. This assessment is made jointly by our medical and security professionals.
• For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
Location Guides andmedical alerts, and the COVID-19 information within thePandemic
Information Site, includingTravel Restrictions, Flight Operations and Screening.
In-country people
• Closely follow all official directives and abide by them. Monitor reliable sources for
information relating to changes to directives.
• Understand your organisation’s medical and security triggers for changes to in-country
posture.
Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. People who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three to six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.
Info:

Advice:
• If in Central, Southern or Tel Aviv district, minimise movement in the coming days and
abide by all official directives issued by the emergency services and civil authorities.
Ensure to stay in the vicinity of the nearest shelter or protected space.
• Defer all travel to locations within 25 miles (40km) of the border with Gaza until further
notice.
• Understand the immediate actions to take upon hearing an air raid siren and remain
aware of the location of the nearest shelter or protected space. The length of an air raid
siren represents the amount of time one has to enter their secure space. When in a
secure space, remain there for at least ten minutes. If another air raid warning is heard
during this time, remain inside the secure space for a further ten minutes.
• For further information on what to do during a rocket attack, please visit the Israel
Defense Forces Home Front Command website (access from outside Israel may not
be possible) and consult this Preparedness Information document.
• The above advice is not exhaustive. Consult our Standing Travel Advice for Israel for
full recommendations.
Info:
Israel: Minimise non-essential movement in Southern, Central,
Tel Aviv districts following intensification of rocket fire

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Defer all travel to Israel and the Palestinian Territories until at least 17 May due to the
current security escalation and entry restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic.
In-country workforce
• Minimise non-essential movement in Central, Southern and Tel Aviv districts (all
Israel). Abide by all official directives issued by the emergency services and civil
authorities. Stay in the vicinity of the nearest shelter or protected space.
• Defer all travel to locations within 25 miles (40km) of the border with Gaza.
• Understand the immediate actions to take upon hearing an air raid siren and remain
aware of the location of the nearest shelter or protected space. The length of an air raid
siren represents the amount of time one has to enter their secure space. When in a
secure space, remain there for at least ten minutes. If another air raid warning is heard
during this time, remain inside the secure space for a further ten minutes.
• For further information on what to do during a rocket attack, please visit the IDF Home
Front Command website (access from outside Israel may not be possible) and consult
Front Command website (access from outside Israel may not be possible) and consult
this Preparedness Information document.
• Maintain situational awareness and exercise vigilance due to the potential for militant
attacks. Targets may include religious gatherings, public transport, security force
premises and personnel and locations where members of the ultra-Orthodox Jewish
community or those of perceived Arab ethnicity regularly gather.
• Ensure regular check-ins with line managers and other in-country workforce. Keep
emergency contact details (such as phone numbers) on your person.
• Avoid all gatherings due to the risk of unrest and a significant security force response.
In areas affected by recurrent unrest, minimise movement after dark due to the
potential for further violence. Liaise with local contacts and monitor local news to
remain apprised of developments. Expect, but do not be unduly alarmed by, a
heightened security force presence. Always carry relevant identification and follow all
directives of the security forces.
• As Israeli airspace and Ben Gurion International Airport (TLV, Tel Aviv) may be
periodically closed, reconfirm all flight itineraries in the coming days and anticipate
residual disruption at the airport after such closures.
• Abide by all COVID-19-related regulations. Do not attempt to bypass any restrictions
unless cleared to do so.
• The above advice is not exhaustive. Consult our Standing Travel Advice for Israel and
the Palestinian Territories for full recommendations.
Jerusalem
• Defer visits to Jerusalem’s Old City and flashpoint neighbourhoods until at least 17
May. Exercise caution and be prepared to leave an area at the first sign of unrest
should you wish to visit the area, particularly the Temple Mount/Haram al-Sharif
complex, which houses al-Aqsa mosque. Ensure you have emergency contact
numbers on your person.
West Bank (Palestinian Territories)
• Abide by the current COVID-19 restrictions related to the ongoing lockdown.
• Avoid all gatherings due to the risk of localised unrest. Exercise caution if travelling in
the vicinity of Israeli settlements, as well as on routes and junctions leading to them
and their surrounding areas.
• Have flexible travel plans as the Israeli security forces may impose curfews, travel
bans, road closures or similar restrictions in areas of the West Bank with little or no
notice.
Gaza
• We continue to advise against all travel to Gaza, where the travel risks are rated as
EXTREME. Organisations with workforce in Gaza should contact us for itinerary- and
profile-specific security advice.
• Liaise with your dedicated security provider to ascertain the feasibility of movement.
Reconfirm the status of the Erez/Beit Hanoun border crossing immediately prior to
outbound journeys.
• Our providers' capacity to provide on-the-ground support is limited and subject to
change at short notice. Ensure you are registered with your relevant embassy and all
relevant warden networks, including the UN and relevant NGO co-ordination groups.
Info:

precautions until at least 17 May due to continued hostilities,

• Avoid all gatherings due to the risk of unrest and a significant security force response.
In areas affected by recurrent unrest, minimise movement after dark due to the
potential for further violence. Liaise with local contacts and monitor local news to
remain apprised of developments. Expect, but do not be unduly alarmed by, a
heightened security force presence. Always carry relevant identification and follow all
directives of the security forces.
• As Israeli airspace and Ben Gurion International Airport (TLV, Tel Aviv) may be
periodically closed, reconfirm all flight itineraries in the coming days and anticipate
residual disruption at the airport after such closures.
• Abide by all COVID-19-related regulations. Do not attempt to bypass any restrictions
unless cleared to do so.
• The above advice is not exhaustive. Consult our Standing Travel Advice for Israel and
the Palestinian Territories for full recommendations.
Jerusalem
• Defer visits to Jerusalem’s Old City and flashpoint neighbourhoods until at least 17
May. Exercise caution and be prepared to leave an area at the first sign of unrest
should you wish to visit the area, particularly the Temple Mount/Haram al-Sharif
complex, which houses al-Asqa mosque. Ensure you have emergency contact
numbers on your person.
West Bank (Palestinian Territories)
• Abide by the current COVID-19 restrictions related to the ongoing lockdown.
• Avoid all gatherings due to the risk of localised unrest. Exercise caution if travelling in
the vicinity of Israeli settlements, as well as on routes and junctions leading to them
and their surrounding areas.
• Have flexible travel plans as the Israeli security forces may impose curfews, travel
bans, road closures or similar restrictions in areas of the West Bank with little or no
notice.

aware of the location of the nearest shelter or protected space. The length of an air raid
siren represents the amount of time one has to enter their secure space. When in a
siren represents the amount of time one has to enter their secure space. When in a
secure space, remain there for at least ten minutes. If another air raid warning is heard
during this time, remain inside the secure space for a further ten minutes.

premises and personnel and locations where members of the ultra-Orthodox Jewish
community or those of perceived Arab ethnicity regularly gather.

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Essential travel to Montenegro may be possible subject to an itinerary- and profile-
specific review. This assessment is made jointly by our medical and security
professionals.
• For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
Location Guides and medical alerts and the COVID-19 information within the
Pandemic Information Site, including Travel Restrictions, Flight Operations and
Screening.
In-country people
• Closely follow all official directives and abide by them. Monitor reliable sources for
information relating to changes to directives.
• Understand your organisation’s medical and security triggers for changes to in-country
posture.
Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. People who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three-to-six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.

transport, communication and security arrangements prior to travelling. If conducting
significant overland travel, do so during daylight hours only.
• Crime poses a significant risk in Mexico and criminals are often armed. If accosted,
avoid doing anything to resist or antagonise the assailant. If you are involved in a
serious crime, contact your local embassy or consulate, as well as your local support
network.
• Monitor our Mexico alerts for updates.
Info:
Mexico: Tamaulipas state: Exercise caution amid likely crime
increase following killing of cartel leader

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Essential travel to Pakistan may be possible subject to an itinerary- and profile-specific
review. This assessment is made jointly by our medical and security professionals.
• For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
Location Guides and medical alerts and the COVID-19 information within the
Pandemic Information Site, including Travel Restrictions, Flight Operations and
Screening.
In-country people
• Closely follow all official directives and abide by them. Monitor reliable sources of
information relating to changes to directives.
• Understand your company's medical and security triggers for changes to in-country
posture.
Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. People who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three to six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.
Info:
Pakistan: COVID-19: Abide by official directives following
extension of restrictions until 30 May

Advice:
• If in Central, Southern or Tel Aviv district, minimise movement until 13 May and abide
by all official directives.
• Understand the immediate actions to take on hearing air raid warnings and be aware of
the location of the nearest air raid shelter. The length of an air raid siren represents the
amount of time one has to enter secure space. When in a secure space, remain there
for at least ten minutes. If another air raid warning is heard during this time, remain
inside the secure space for a further ten minutes.
• For further information on what to do during a rocket attack, please visit the Israel
Defense Forces Home Front Command website (access from outside Israel may not
be possible).
• As temporary closures of airspace and Ben Gurion International Airport may take
place, reconfirm all flight itineraries in the coming days and anticipate residual
disruption at the airport after such closures.
• Defer all travel to locations within 25 miles (40km) of the border with Gaza until further
notice. If you are already in these locations, minimise movement and ensure you stay
in the vicinity of the nearest air raid shelter.
• Monitor our Israel alerts for updates.
Info:
Israel: Central, Southern, Tel Aviv districts: Minimise movement
until 13 May amid fresh rocket attacks

aware of the location of the nearest air raid shelter. Understand the immediate actions
to take on hearing air raid warnings. The length of an air raid siren represents the
amount of time one has to enter their secure space. When in a secure space, remain
there for at least ten minutes. If another air raid warning is heard during this time,
remain inside the secure space for a further ten minutes.
• For further information on what to do during a rocket attack, please visit the Israel
Defense Forces (IDF) Home Front Command website (access from outside Israel may
not be possible).
• Monitor our Israel alerts for updates.
Info:
Israel: Tel Aviv district: Stand fast amid ongoing rocket attack;
account for staff

Advice:
In-country workforce
• Continue to defer non-essential travel to affected areas, including Gujarat, as well as
Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu union territories, until 19 May.
• We do not hold specific information on flights or other transport. Reconfirm schedules
with the relevant service provider before setting out. In the event of cancellations, your
travel agent will be able to help with alternative arrangements.
• Monitor the IMDwebsite for the latest forecast and be prepared to adjust itineraries at
short notice.
Those in areas forecast to be affected
• Minimise movement in the aforementioned areas and follow all official directives. If in
an affected location, stand fast in or move to a secure accommodation with a
confirmed supply of essential commodities such as water, food and electricity.
• Stay away from rivers and other water bodies, as well as low-lying coastal areas, which
are susceptible to storm surges and flooding.
• Any essential movement should be undertaken after confirming that intended
destinations and routes are unaffected by flooding. Avoid surge-prone or flooded
areas. Ensure that your vehicle is in good condition and appropriately equipped for the
weather conditions before setting out.
• Disruption to essential services, such as electricity, is likely in worst-affected areas.
Charge all communications devices and laptops. Ensure you have access to back-up
charging options such as power banks.
• Prepare a 'grab bag' with essentials such as a torch, water and high-energy foods, in
case an emergency relocation becomes necessary.
Info:
India: Western region: Continue to defer non-essential travel to
areas most affected by Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Tauktae
(Revised)

Advice:
• Crime is a significant concern in Brazil and criminals are often armed. If targeted, do
nothing to resist or antagonise the assailant(s).
• If you are in the vicinity of a violent incident, quickly move to a secure location as soon
as it is safe to do so and remain there until the situation normalises.
• Plan routes through Rio de Janeiro in advance. Use official taxis or hire a private
vehicle and driver. Do not self-drive unless you are familiar with local conditions as
GPS systems may direct travellers through favelas (shanty towns). Public transport is
not suitable for travellers.
• Consult our city security guide for Rio de Janeiro city for more information on crime.
• Monitor our Brazil alerts for updates.
Info:
Brazil: Rio de Janeiro: Shoot-out during police operation in
Jacarezinho favela highlights incidental risks posed by violent
crime

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Defer all travel to Lebanon due to restrictions related to COVID-19. This assessment is
made jointly by our medical and security professionals.
• For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
Location Guides and medical alerts and the COVID-19 information within the
Pandemic Information Site, including Travel Restrictions, Flight Operations and
Screening.
In-country people
• Closely follow all official directives and abide by them. Monitor reliable sources for
information relating to changes to directives.
• Understand your organisation’s medical and security triggers for changes to in-country
posture.
Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick; people who are sick face the risk of being tested and
quarantined. Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like
symptoms, following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three to six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.
Info:
Lebanon: COVID-19: Abide by tightened restrictions from 13-15
May during Eid al-Fitr festival

Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. Travellers who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene: Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three to six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.
Info:
Pakistan: COVID-19: Abide by official directives from 16 May
amid easing of restrictions

Advice:
• Travel to rural Sindh should be for business-critical purposes only due to high levels of
banditry and poor police control. A journey-specific threat assessment and robust
journey management planning is essential. Travel should be conducted during daylight
hours only and with professional security support, avoiding secondary routes where
practical.
• Essential travel to Karachi should be conducted with stringent precautions.
Professional security support is recommended for movement outside the central and
southern districts.
• Remain alert to your surroundings and report any suspicious behaviour and/or objects
to the authorities. Minimise time spent around likely targets for militant attacks, both
stationary and in transit. These include security force personnel and installations,
religious sites and densely populated unsecured areas such as markets.
• Avoid train travel due to the potential for militant attacks. Public transport is not
recommended for business travellers.
• Monitor our alerts on Pakistan for updates.
Info:
Pakistan: Sindh province: Explosion targeting railway tracks
underlines militancy risks, need to avoid train travel

or an interior room on the lowest floor of your building. Follow all directives issued by
the authorities.

hold specific information on flights or other modes of transport. Contact the
relevant airport or airline to confirm the status of flights before setting out. In the event
of cancellations, your travel agent will be able to assist with alternative arrangements.

In-country workforce
• Defer non-essential travel to areas expected to be affected in Gujarat and Dadra and
Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu union territory until 19 May. Such districts are
Amreli, Devbhoomi Dwarka, Gir Somnath, Jamnagar, Junagarh, Kutch, Morbi,
Porbandar, Rajkot (all Gujarat) and Diu (Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu).
• We do not hold specific information on flights or other transport. Reconfirm

schedules with the relevant service provider before setting out. In the event of

Those in areas forecast to be affected
• Minimise movement in the aforementioned districts and follow all official directives. If in
an affected location, stand fast in or move to a secure accommodation with a
confirmed supply of essential commodities such as water, food and electricity.
• Stay away from rivers and other water bodies, as well as low-lying coastal areas, which
are susceptible to storm surges and flooding.
• Any essential movement should be undertaken after confirming that intended
destinations and routes are unaffected by flooding.Avoid surge-prone or flooded areas.
Ensure that your vehicle is in good condition and appropriately equipped for the
weather conditions before setting out.
• Disruption to essential services, such as electricity, is likely in worst-affected areas.
Charge all communications devices and laptops. Ensure you have access to back-up
charging options such as power banks.
• Prepare a 'grab bag' with essentials such as a torch, water and high-energy foods, in
case an emergency relocation becomes necessary.

Advice:
Managers
• Closely monitor COVID-19-related developments for their impact on staff mobility or
associated security risks.
• Ensure access to reliable, nuanced information to inform workforce communication and
business decision-making.
• Regularly re-evaluate whether it is best for your international assignees and
dependants to remain in-country or to relocate. If you decide to relocate them, this
should be done as soon as possible.
• Consider the circumstances that influence their ability to remain in-country and work
with the restrictions, directives and mitigation measures of the authorities. These
include:
o The ability to procure basic goods and services.
o Access to communications.
o Access to quality medical care, the usual standard of local medical care and the
local health system’s capability to manage a sudden surge in demand.
o The ability and comfort level of international assignees to stay for an extended
period at their destination with limited or no support.
• Ensure the strict compliance of your workforce with local government containment
efforts.
• Ensure country-specific Business Continuity Plans are regularly reviewed and focused
on next steps.
In-country international assignees
• Carefully consider whether it is best for you and your family to remain where you are
now or to relocate. Plan accordingly.
• Review the circumstances that influence your ability to remain in-country (and work
with the restrictions, directives and mitigation measures of the authorities).
• Review your personal need to be in an alternative location.
• Review your personal need to be in an alternative location.

information relating to changes to directives.

• Ensure you have provisions in place at your accommodation and worksites to support
a stand-fast period of seven days (i.e. food, water, medicine).

Advice:
• Exercise heightened vigilance during the electoral cycle. Seek expert itinerary- and
profile-specific advice prior to travel to Mexico.
• Travel to HIGH travel risk states should be for essential purposes and should be
arranged in close liaison with local contacts. Carefully plan all aspects of your itinerary
and be confident in accommodation, transport, communication and security
arrangements prior to travel. Measures include travelling with a private vehicle and
trusted driver and undertaking movement in daylight hours only. Journey plans should
allow sufficient time for delays, such as a breakdown.
• Where possible, avoid all election-related gatherings and polling stations to mitigate the
risk of incidental exposure to unrest. Should demonstrators, armed groups or the
security forces begin to gather, quickly and calmly vacate the area.
• Anticipate heightened security and associated disruption during election-related
events. Liaise with local contacts for information on planned rallies and allow additional
time to reach your destination.
• Monitor our alerts on Mexico for further updates.
Info:
Mexico: Avoid political gatherings, exercise vigilance around
midterm elections on 6 June

Inbound travellers

Health advice
• Obtain profile-specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick. Travellers who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu-like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to.
• Avoid crowded places. In public areas, as much as possible, keep three to six feet (1-2
metres) away from others.

directives despite further easing of restrictions from 17 May

Advice:
• Journeys to most MEDIUM travel risk areas – including the capital Riyadh, Dammam
(Eastern province) and Jeddah (Mecca province) – can continue with standard
precautions.
• Journeys to strategic locations, such as government and military interests, oil facilities
and airports, in the MEDIUM travel risk areas of Asir, Jizan and Najran provinces within
68 miles (110km) of the border with Yemen should be for essential purposes only.
Monitor events closely during your stay in these areas.
• Avoid non- essential journeys to the HIGH travel risk areas within 18.6 miles (30km) of
the border with Iraq and Yemen. Essential travel to these locations should be
conducted only with a trusted bilingual local guide, ideally with a strong local contact
network, and with solid journey- management plans. Defer all travel to Najran city and
its immediate surroundings due to the heightened threat of indiscriminate cross- border
strikes.
• Exercise heightened caution around likely targets for Houthi attacks. These include
government and military interests, energy infrastructure and airports. Remain indoors
and take cover under or behind a hard surface if an explosion is heard, as falling debris
from a missile or drone interception can pose risks to those in the vicinity.
• Monitor our alerts on Saudi Arabia for updates.
Info:
Saudi Arabia: Asir, Jizan provinces: Fresh cross-border attacks
highlight need for caution around potential targets

Advice:
Do the following:
• All travellers are recommended to be fully immunised (including a booster if available)
prior to arrival in country. Carry proof of your polio vaccination status in case it is
requested on entry.
• Select food, water and other beverages carefully:
o Drink only boiled or bottled water, or sealed carbonated beverages.
o Choose food that has been thoroughly cooked while fresh and is served hot.
o Avoid ice, raw fruit, and raw vegetables (including salad).
• Pay attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently, especially before eating.
• To prevent international spread of polio, the World Health Organization recommends
that all residents and visitors who have been in the country for more than 4 weeks
receive a dose of polio vaccine (IPV) within 4 weeks to 12 months of travel. Travellers
should carry the document on which their polio vaccination status is recorded. They
may be asked to show proof of polio vaccination at departure or while entering other
countries.
Info: Benin: Polio

Advice:
Inbound/outbound business travellers
• Defer all travel to Chad due to the current security situation and overarching impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic.
• For those departing the country, abide by COVID-19 requirements by showing a
negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test result, taken no more than 72 hours
prior to departure. Ensure you comply with relevant COVID-19 restrictions at the
onward destination.
Remaining essential workforce
• All movement should be conducted with a robust risk assessment. Confirm the
feasibility of journeys with local contacts or security providers in case of roadblocks en
route to your destination.
• Prepare to minimise movement on 8 May. Plan all movement around this date
accordingly.
• Non-essential workforce and dependants should defer their return to Chad until at
least 10 May.
• We do not hold information on specific flights. Only undertake travel to Ndjamena
International Airport (NDJ) upon confirmation of flight schedules. Appropriate check-ins
should be made with your relevant manager upon departure and arrival at the facility.
• Anticipate a visible military presence and ensure you have valid identification on your
person for all related checks. Checkpoints may be erected at short notice. Identify
alternative routes for all essential movement.
• Ensure the ability to stand fast for a minimum of seven days with access to secure
accommodation, tested, multi-channel and resilient means of communication and
procedures, and a robust local assistance network. Ensure access to adequate stocks
of essential supplies, including food, water, back-up power, fuel, cash and essential
medication.
• Maintain alternative modes of communication and anticipate potential mobile internet
outages and spontaneous cuts to mobile telecommunications. Consider purchasing
multiple SIM cards, including from neighbouring countries.
• Remain apprised of the situation through International SOS alerts and diplomatic and
security contacts. Do not act upon unverified information.
Info:
Chad: Minimise movement on 8 May during fresh opposition
protests; monitor developments in coming days

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• Defer non-essential travel amid the COVID-19 pandemic and associated restrictions.
For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
Location Guides and medical alerts and the COVID-19 information within the
Pandemic Information Site, including Travel Restrictions, Flight Operations and
Screening.
In-country workforce
• Normal movement can resume with caution. Closely monitor political developments
and remain apprised of upcoming gatherings. All protests should be avoided due to the
potential for unrest.
• Avoid non-essential travel to: Tibesti, Borkou, Ennedi East, Ennedi West and Kanem
regions; areas within 18 miles (30km) of borders with the Central African Republic and
Sudan; and areas of Lac region located west of Bol, which are also rated as HIGH risk.
Travel to these areas should be conducted with security support and after seeking
itinerary-specific advice.
• Anticipate a visible military presence and ensure you have valid identification on your
person for all related checks. Checkpoints may be erected at short notice. Identify
alternative routes for all essential movement.
• Ensure the ability to stand fast for a minimum of 72 hours in urban centres and one
week in remote areas. This should include access to secure accommodation, as well
as tested, multi-channel and resilient means of communication and procedures, and a
robust local assistance network. Ensure access to adequate stocks of essential
supplies, including food, water, back-up power, fuel, cash and essential medication.
• Maintain alternative modes of communication and anticipate potential mobile internet
outages and spontaneous cuts to mobile telecommunications. Consider purchasing
multiple SIM cards, including from neighbouring countries.
• Remain apprised of the situation through International SOS alerts and diplomatic and

Chad: Monitor developments, adopt enhanced preparedness

Advice:
Inbound/outbound business travellers
• Defer all travel to Chad until at least 10 May due to the current security situation and
restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic. This includes non-essential workforce
and dependants planning to return to the country.
• For those departing the country, abide by COVID-19 requirements by showing a
negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test result, taken no more than 72 hours
prior to departure. Ensure you comply with relevant COVID-19 restrictions at the
onward destination.
Remaining essential workforce
• Normal movement can resume with caution. Closely monitor political developments
and information on gatherings, and avoid all protests as a precaution.
• We do not hold information on specific flights. Only undertake travel to Ndjamena
International Airport (NDJ) upon confirmation of flight schedules. Appropriate check-ins
should be made with your relevant manager upon departure and arrival at the facility.
• Anticipate a visible military presence and ensure you have valid identification on your
person for all related checks. Checkpoints may be erected at short notice. Identify
alternative routes for all essential movement.
• Ensure the ability to stand fast for a minimum of seven days with access to secure
accommodation, tested, multi-channel and resilient means of communication and
procedures, and a robust local assistance network. Ensure access to adequate stocks
of essential supplies, including food, water, back-up power, fuel, cash and essential
medication.
• Maintain alternative modes of communication and anticipate potential mobile internet
outages and spontaneous cuts to mobile telecommunications. Consider purchasing
multiple SIM cards, including from neighbouring countries.
• Remain apprised of the situation through International SOS alerts and diplomatic and
security contacts. Do not act upon unverified information.

Chad: Normal movement can resume with caution; monitor
developments in coming days

Advice:
• Monitor the Maldives Meteorological Service website for up- to- date information on
prevailing weather conditions and related warnings. Be prepared to adjust itineraries
accordingly.
• Liaise with local contacts to ascertain the status of roads before setting out. Do not
attempt to drive through flooded areas. Turn around and find an alternative route to
your destination. Do not self-drive unless very familiar with local conditions.
• Avoid walking through submerged areas due to the possibility of uncovered drains,
deep ditches and other obstructions that are often unmarked and can prove fatal.
• Charge all communication devices and laptops. Ensure you have access to back- up
charging options, such as power banks.
• Monitor our alerts on the Maldives for updates.
Info:
Maldives: Exercise caution, plan journeys accounting for
disruption caused by ongoing adverse weather

Advice:
Inbound business travellers
• International SOS maintains its standing advice to defer all travel to Myanmar due to
restrictions related to COVID- 19. The driver for this advice now applies equally to the
prevailing security situation, until otherwise indicated. This assessment is made jointly
by our medical and security professionals.
In-country workforce
• Essential movement should be carried out after liaising with local contacts to confirm
the status of routes and feasibility of travel due to potential roadblocks. Unrest may
occur with little warning, even in areas that are not traditionally protest hotspots.
Backup plans should also be in place in the event that the journey is interrupted,
including potential safe havens en route to the destination.
• Stand fast in a safe location if in the vicinity of unrest. Should protesters or the security
forces begin to gather in your vicinity, vacate the area to minimise the risk of injury,
head to a safe haven immediately and remain there until the situation has stabilised.
• Before conducting any intercity movement or movement outside major urban centres,
seek a profile- and itinerary- specific risk assessment from security professionals to
ensure appropriate precautions, taking into account the potential for short- notice
imposition of restrictions on road movement, access to certain areas and
communications services.
• Expect heightened security on the streets especially in the capital Naypyitaw,
Mandalay (Mandalay region) and Yangon. C arry relevant identification documents to
ease passage through security checks.
• Installations affiliated to the ruling military State Administration Council (SAC), including
military, police, and local administrative buildings and personnel, are common targets
of explosions and EAO attacks. Minimise time spent in the vicinity of these locations to
mitigate the risk of getting caught up in any incident.
• Maintain heightened awareness in public spaces, especially in the vicinity of parked
vehicles or publicly accessible containers such as rubbish bins , due to the threat of
hidden explosives.
• Be prepared for further short- notice disruption to telecommunications services.
Maintain a list of emergency contacts, both electronically and on paper. Always keep
copies with you. Register all contacts on your mobile phone. Ensure that you are aware
of and compliant with your organisation's communications and incident management
protocols. Check in or communicate your status and whereabouts during and after any
period of communications disruption.
• Power cuts are expected in the coming weeks. Ensure your accommodation has a
backup generator and all communication devices are fully charged as a general
backup generator and all communication devices are fully charged as a general
precaution.
• Ensure you have the ability to stand fast for a protracted period with access to secure
accommodation, tested communications procedures and a resilient local assistance
network. Ensure access to adequate stocks of essential supplies, including food, water,
backup power, fuel, cash and essential medication.
• Those travelling near ongoing protests face the risk of arbitrary detention and incidental
injury. The police may stop you for questioning, check identification and conduct
searches of electronic devices for politically sensitive material.
• Continue to monitor developments closely. All information circulating on social media
and news channels should be verified via reliable sources.
Health advice from International SOS
• Obtain profile- specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID- 19 virus. Review
the necessity of travelling against the potential risks.
• Do not travel if you are sick. People who are sick risk being tested and quarantined.
Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu- like symptoms,
following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene. Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever you are
required to. Even if it is not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in
public.
• Avoidcrowdedplaces.Inpublicareas,asmuchaspossible,keepthree-to-sixfeet(1- 2
metres) away from others.

Myanmar: Incidental risks remain elevated amid explosions,
periodic unrest; conduct essential movement after confirming
status of routes

• Installations affiliated with the ruling military State Administration Council (SAC),
including military, police and local administrative buildings or personnel, are often
targeted in bombings. Minimise time spent in the vicinity of these locations as a
precaution.
• Maintain heightened awareness in public spaces, especially in the vicinity of parked
vehicles or publicly accessible containers such as rubbish bins, due to the threat of
hidden explosives.
• Expect heightened security near targeted areas. Carry relevant identification
documents to ease passage through security checks and follow all official directives.
• Monitor our Myanmar alerts for updates.
Info:
Myanmar: Yangon: Explosion near UNDP building highlights
need for vigilance, incidental risks

Advice:
Managers
• Closely monitor COVID- 19- related developments for impacts on staff mobility or
associated security risks.
• Ensure access to reliable, nuanced information to inform workforce communication and
business decision-making.
• Regularly re- evaluate whether it is best for your international assignees and
dependants to remain in- country or to relocate. If you decide to relocate them, this
should be done as soon as possible.
• Consider the circumstances that influence their ability to remain in- country and work
with the restrictions, directives and mitigation measures of the authorities. These
include:
o The ability to procure basic goods and services.
o Access to communications.
o Access to quality medical care, the usual standard of local medical care and the local
health system’s capability to manage a sudden surge in demand.
o The ability and comfort level of international assignees to stay for an extended period
at their destination with limited or no support.
• Ensure the strict compliance of your workforce with local government containment
efforts. Contact the local authorities to reconfirm the zonal classification (containment
or non- containment) of your sites and whether your business operations are permitted
accordingly.
• Ensure country- specific Business Continuity Plans are regularly reviewed and focused
on next steps.
In-country international assignees
• Carefully consider whether it is best for you and your family to remain where you are
now or to relocate. Plan accordingly.
• Review the circumstances that influence your ability to remain in- country (and work
with the restrictions, directives and mitigation measures of the authorities).
• Review your personal needs to be in an alternative location.
In-country workforce
• Closely follow all official directives and abide by them. Monitor reliable sources for
information relating to changes to directives.
• Understand your company’s medical and security triggers for changes to in- country
posture.
• Defer non- essential domestic travel that would entail long periods of time in close
proximity to other members of the public.
• Ensure you have provisions in place at your accommodation and work sites to support
a stand-fast period of seven days (i.e. food, water, medicine).
Inbound business travellers
• Defer all travel to Nepal due to restrictions related to COVID- 19. This assessment is
made jointly by our medical and security professionals.
• Monitor the Department of Immigration website for the latest information regarding
conditions for entry into Nepal, as well as related quarantine measures. Avoid rumours
and misinformation. Monitor and confirm developments by liaising with the authorities,
including the nearest Nepali embassy or consulate.
• For further information, advice and current restrictions, see the International SOS
LocationGuidesandmedicalalertsandtheCOVID-19informationwithinthe Pandemic
Information Site, including Travel Restrictions, Flight Operations and Screening.
Health advice
• Obtain profile- specific advice prior to any travel, taking into account the extent to which
your age and health may make you more vulnerable to the COVID-19 virus.
• Do not travel if you are sick; people who are sick face the risk of being tested and
quarantined. Monitor your health and seek medical attention if you develop flu- like
symptoms, following the local procedure for your location.
• Pay strict attention to hygiene: Wash your hands frequently and carry hand sanitiser for
use when soap and water are not readily available. Wear a mask whenever required
to. Even if not required, consider wearing a mask if you have to go out in public.
• Avoidcrowdedplaces.Inpublicareas,asmuchaspossible,keepthree-to-sixfeet(1- 2
metres) away from others.

The U.S. Embassy in San Jos has issued the following Travel Alert for American citizens in
Costa Rica:
Event: Media Reporting Sporadic Protests and Road Blocks Across Costa Rica.
Government of Costa Rica Extends Nationwide COVID-19 Related Driving Restrictions.
Please Read Entire Message.
Nationwide protests:
Costa Rican media outlets and social media sources are reporting that Rescate Nacional
has called for road blocks at various points across Costa Rica this week to protest the
Government s negotiations with the International Monetary Fund, the Public employment
bill, and increases in fuel prices. The Embassy has received confirmed reports of minor
confrontations between police and protestors and temporarily blocked roads at several
locations across Costa Rica. The majority of protests in Costa Rica are non-violent in
nature. However, you should exercise caution in the vicinity of any large gatherings,
protests, or demonstrations. The Embassy will continue to review the situation and will
provide additional information as needed. U.S. citizens traveling within Costa Rica may
wish to consult with local media sources or traffic Apps to identify possible road closures
or delays in specific areas.
Nationwide Restrictions:
Costa Rica has confirmed 271,478 cases of COVID-19 as of May 11, 2021. 1,280 people are
hospitalized with COVID-19, 466 of them in intensive care. Costa Rica has reported 3,430
COVID-19-related deaths since March 2, 2020. The Costa Rican government has re-
introduced weekend and weekday nationwide driving restrictions in response to an
increase in coronavirus cases and hospitalizations. See below for a summary of current
COVID-19 related restrictions. For an unofficial English language translation of current
restrictions, please follow this link. For an official Spanish language list of all new and
existing sanitary measures, visit presidencia.go.cr/alertas.

throughout Connecticut plan to participate in a strike starting at 6:00 AM local time on

https://www.eltiempo.com/bogota/paro-nacional-en-vivo-hoy-16-de-mayo-protestas-y-
marchas-bogota-en-directo-588829
The U.S. Embassy in Bogota reports that the following protests have been planned across
Bogota for Wednesday, May 19:
8:00 AM local time Demonstration at Portal Americas
8:00 AM Demonstration at Parque Virrey
9:00 AM March starting at Parque Nacional; ending point unknown
10:00 AM March starting at Portal del Sur and proceeding to Estado el Campin
1:00 PM Demonstration at Parque Banderas
2:00 PM Demonstration at Monumento a los Heroes
The pubic is advised to closely monitor local media outlets, as additional bouts of protest
activity could potentially crop up with little or no warning. Widespread protest activity has
continued on a daily basis since late April. What began as a series of demonstrations
against a proposed tax reform initiative has since broadened into a much wider protest
movement. Many activists have demanded that the country s riot police force (the Mobile
Anti-Disturbances Squadron, or ESMAD ) be dismantled following a series of incidents in
which officers have been accused of using excessive force. Student groups, labor unions,
indigenous organizations, and a range of other activist groups also continue to take to the
streets to raise disparate grievances spanning issues such as healthcare, wealth
inequality, and working conditions.
Protests have repeatedly degenerated in wider episodes of unrest, sometimes entailing
looting, arson, roadblocks, and/or violent clashes with security forces. Dozens of bus
stops remain out of service throughout Bogota and its environs due to recent vandalism.
All large public gatherings should be avoided as much as possible to minimize the risk of
being caught up in incidental violence. Motorists are advised not to attempt to bypass
roadblocks, as doing so could elicit a violent response from protesters.

• Avoid affected areas. If you are nearby, minimise movement until the situation

• Monitor our alerts on the Palestinian Territories for updates.

Rotunda Hospital, located near Parnell Square E and Parnell St. Health authorities have
shut down all health IT systems in the country while technicians can assess the extent to

patients who are at least 36 weeks pregnant. The system for COVID-19 vaccinations has
not been affected, and appointments are expected to resume on Friday. The ransomware

disruptions to health services throughout the day.

Honda and Toyota are suspending at least some production operations in Malaysia due to
the country s COVID-19 restrictions. Honda, which produces some 100,000 cars and
300,000 motorcycles in Malaysia every year, will close its plant in Pegoh, Malacca until at
least June 15. Toyota will stop its direct production in Malaysia for an unspecified period of
time, while its Daihatsu subsidiary will cease manufacturing until at least June 14. Toyota
built around 50,000 cars in the country in 2020, and Daihatsu produced approximately
220,000. Expect associated supply chain issues while the shutdowns remain in place.

The U.S. Embassy in Lima has issued the following Health Alert for American citizens in
Peru:
On May 8, 2021, the Government of Peru announced the extension of emergency self-
quarantine and movement restrictions for three weeks due to high levels of COVID-19
spread, effective Monday, May 10, 2021 to May 30, 2021.
The Jorge Chavez International airport remains open, and domestic land and air
transportation continue with reduced occupancy.
As of May 10, 2021, Lima and Callao are now considered on 'Very High Alert.'
Regions considered on 'Extreme Alert' include Amazonas (Chachapoyas), Ancash
(Huarmey), Apurimac (Abancay, Chincheros, y Grau), Arequipa (Islaya), Ayacucho
(Huamanga, Huanta, y La Mar), Cajamarca (Hualgayoc), Cusco (Cusco, Anta, Canchis),
Huancavelica (Tayacaja), Huanuco (Ambo y Leoncio Prado), Ica (Chincha), Junin
(Chanchamayo, Concepcion, Jauja, Satipo, Tarma, Yauli), La Libertad (Vir ), Lambayeque
(Chiclayo y Lambayeque), Madre de Dios (Tambopata), Pasco (Oxapampa), Puno (Melgar,
Puno, San Roman, Yunguyo), San Mart n (Bellavista y Lamas).
The Loreto region is considered 'High Alert.'
The Government of Peru will update quarantine assessments every three weeks instead of
every two weeks.
Additional Details for Extreme Alert levels:
Monday-Saturday curfew is 9:00p.m. to 4:00 a.m.
Sunday curfew is 24 hours.
On Sundays, personal vehicles are prohibited. Taking taxis and public transportation is
allowed.
On all days of the week, restaurants may deliver from 4:00 a.m. until 11:00 p.m. Pharmacy
delivery is available 24 hours. Taking taxis and public transportation is allowed.
Monday Saturday, supermarkets and grocery stores are open at 40% occupancy.
Restaurants are open at 30% occupancy. Banks are open at 40% occupancy. Salons, spas,
and barbershops at 40% occupancy by appointment. Casinos, gyms, movie theaters,
churches are open at 20% occupancy.
Beaches remain closed.

Media sources report that two World War Two-era bombs were discovered at an
unspecified location near the D sseldorf Airport (IATA: DUS). Sources note that the bombs
are both five and ten quintals, and will be defused today, Monday, May 10. Around 2,500
people must evacuate a 500-meter radius (1,640 feet) near the defusing site, which is
apparently along Flughafenstrasse. While most of the people impacted are airport
employees, another 3,000 more people are affected when the radius goes up to 1,000
meters (3,280 feet). The two zones are called Danger Area A and Danger Area B,
respectively. Those impacted are not permitted to leave their homes or workplaces during
the operation. Despite this, there are no immediate details regarding the time of the
operation. However, sources note that city officials are working to determine a start time.

Advice:
• Avoid affected areas. If you are nearby, minimise movement until the situation
stabilises.
• If planning to travel near an affected area in the coming hours, ensure routes are clear
prior to setting out.
• Monitor our alerts on the Palestinian Territories for updates.

Government sources report that authorities are conducting a controlled detonation of
unexploded ordnance from World War II that was uncovered at a construction site in the
area of Im Karrenberg, near the Dortmund-Kirchderne transit station. Approximately 350
people within 500 meters of the surrounding area have been evacuated as a precaution,
along with several businesses and public transportation services including REWE-
Logistik, Kaufland, Holcim cement works, ICE railway line, Dortmund railway line, and
Thyssen Krupp. Authorities have also closed multiple roads within the restricted area,
including Im Karrenberg, Derner Strasse, Walzwerkstrasse, Sinterstrasse, and
Ruschebrinkstrasse. All public transportation services, as well as all vehicle and
pedestrian traffic is prohibited in the restricted area until the controlled detonation has
been carried out. Expect increased police activity and associated localized disruptions in
the area as authorities operate at the scene.

Advice:
• Avoid affected areas. If you are nearby, minimise movement until the situation
stabilises.
• If planning to travel near an affected area in the coming hours, ensure routes are clear
prior to setting out.

The U.S. Embassy in Panama City has issued the following Health Alert for American
citizens in Panama:
Event: Modified COVID-19 Curfew and Panamanian Entry Requirements
On May 18, Panama s Ministry of Health (MINSA) announced modified curfew hours for the
provinces of Chiriqui and Veraguas, and added curfews to three cities in the province of
Cocl .
Effective May 21, curfew hours in Chiriqui and Veraguas will be from 10:00 p.m. to 4:00
a.m. Monday through Saturday.
Effective May 22, Chiriqui and Veraguas will be under full lockdown from Saturday at 10:00
p.m. until Monday at 4:00 a.m.
Effective May 24, the cities of Penonom , Anton, and La Pintada, in the province of Cocl ,
will begin observing a daily curfew from 10:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m., Monday through Sunday.
Effective May 24, passengers who present a "Full Digital Vaccination Certificate" that
proves the passenger received all required doses at least 14 days prior to their entry, AND
a negative test properly registered in the IATA Travel Pass app 48 hours before entering
the country will not be required to undergo home quarantine nor carry out COVID testing at
the airport.
The rest of Panama remains under nationwide curfew Monday through Sunday from 12:00
a.m. to 4:00 a.m. Additional movement and business restrictions vary by region.
The Embassy reminds U.S. citizens in Panama that it is always obligatory to comply with
local laws.
MINSA reminds citizens and residents of Panama that staying at home, not touching your
face, and washing your hands frequently are the best means of prevention against COVID-
19. It also requires the use of masks when in public.
The Embassy will continue to send messages, as needed, about larger changes that may
affect U.S. citizens in Panama. Minor changes, such as new health recommendations or
reopening of a new sector of Panama's economy, will be placed on the Embassy s COVID-
19 Information page (https://pa.usembassy.go...

On Sunday, the U.S. Embassy in Port of Spain issued the following Health Alert for
American citizens in Trinidad and Tobago:
Event: The U.S. Embassy Port of Spain advises U.S. citizens that the Government of
Trinidad and Tobago has implemented a state of emergency and curfew. These measures
went into effect at midnight on May 15, 2021 and are designed to reduce the spread of the
COVID-19 virus. U.S. citizens are advised to limit movement outside their homes for only
authorized purposes and essential business. The curfew fully restricts movement between
the hours of 9 p.m. and 5 a.m.
Grocery stores, pharmacies and essential businesses will remain open with limited hours.
Due to social distancing requirements, a limited number of customers will be allowed to
enter an essential business at any given time.
All appointments from Monday, May 17 to Wednesday, May 19 are cancelled. We will
reschedule applicants for the following week. In response to the state of emergency, we
will only offer emergency appointments for passport and visa services.
U.S. citizens abroad should register for the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program
(STEP.state.gov) so they can receive important messages from their nearest U.S. Embassy
or Consulate, including timely Alerts and updates to Travel Advisories.
The Health Alert can be viewed in its entirety at this URL: https://tt.usembassy.gov/health-
alert-state-of-emergency-in-trinidad-and-tobago/.

On Thursday, the U.S. Embassy in Paramaribo issued the following Health Alert for
American citizens in Suriname. The message reads, in part:
Location: Suriname
Event:
The Government of Suriname has announced that a lockdown will be in place in Suriname
from Saturday, May 8 at 5pm until Monday, May 10 at 5am. Prior to the lockdown, nightly
curfews continue to be in effect from 8pm to 5am. During the curfew and lockdown
periods, all individuals are instructed to remain in their homes unless otherwise granted
dispensation by Surinamese authorities. Police may detain or fine people who do not abide
by curfew and lockdown regulations. It is mandatory to wear face masks in public.
Gatherings are limited to five people.
For information about flights departing Suriname, to verify schedules, or to book tickets,
please contact your airline directly or visit www.flyslm.com.
The U.S. Embassy continues to monitor the rapidly changing conditions due to COVID-19
in Suriname and in other locations worldwide. The most current information regarding the
impact of COVID-19 may be found at our COVID Information Page.
Actions to Take:
Report symptoms right away if you believe you may have COVID-19 or were exposed to
someone who may have COVID-19 by dialing 178 to reach the designated Ministry of Public
Health COVID-19 hotline.
Visit the COVID-19 crisis page on travel.state.gov for the latest information.
Check with your airline regarding any updated information about your travel plans and/or
restrictions.
Visit our Embassy webpage on COVID-19 for information on conditions in Suriname.
Assistance:
U.S. Embassy Paramaribo, Suriname
Kristalstraat 165, Paramaribo, Suriname
+597 556 700
caparamar@state.gov
https://sr.usembassy.gov
The Health Alert can be viewed in its entirety at the following URL:
https://sr.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-paramaribo-suriname-43/.

čeština: Na Hvozdnici v profilu Jakartovice byl dosažen 3. SPA. Povodně. Voda může
zaplavovat níže položené obydlené oblasti, komunikace, může omezit lidskou činnost a
působit škody v krajině a na majetku. Snížení stability stromů v podmáčené půdě.
Doporučuje se sledovat vývoj situace a jeho prognózu (na www.chmi.cz nebo v médiích).
Uposlechnout pokynů povodňových orgánů, policie a Hasičského záchranného sboru.
Připravit se na možnost dopadů povodně. Některé silnice a mosty mohou být uzavřeny.
Parkovat vozidla na výše položených místech. Vyvarovat se koupání, plavání, jízdy lodí
apod. v korytě toku a bezprostředním okolí a jízdy autem přes povodňovou vodu. Vyhnout
se kontaktu s povodňovou vodou a jejími usazeninami - mohou být kontaminovány. Omezit
pohyb v podmáčených oblastech, kde hrozí pády stromů. english: Flooding. 3rd (highest)
level of flood stage is expected at some river reaches. Water may flood low-lying urban
areas and may affect some human activities. Always follow instruction of local flood
authority, police and fire rescue services. Some roads and bridges may be closed for
traffic. Park your car in high-elevated places. Never walk, swim or drive through flood
water. Flood water may be contaminated – avoid contact with flood water or its sediments.

• HEAVY RAINFALL which may lead to FLASH FLOODING is forecast to develop from
Tuesday morning. There is also a risk of thunderstorms with locally heavier falls.

• HEAVY RAINFALL which may lead to FLASH FLOODING is likely to develop during
Tuesday morning through Eastern, Central and parts of West Gippsland, as well as
along the Otway coast.
Daily rainfall totals of 30 to 60mm are expected broadly through Gippsland and
about the Otways. Higher totals of 50 to 100mm are likely across areas east of
Orbost as well as the ranges east of Mount Baw Baw, with isolated higher totals
possible.
Heavy rain is expected to continue throughout Tuesday before gradually easing on
Tuesday evening and overnight into Wednesday.
A Flood Watch is current for catchments in East Gippsland and parts of West
Gippsland.
Locations which may be affected include Maffra, Bairnsdale and Orbost.

https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3135986/tiananmen-vigil-organiser-
arrested-june-4-anniversary
New Updates:
Media sources indicate that thousands of police forces have been deployed to Victoria
Park from 4:00 PM local time on Friday, June 4, to 12:00 AM on Saturday, June 5, to
prevent demonstrators from gathering. An annual demonstration has been held at Victoria
Park in the past on June 4 to commemorate the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre;
thousands of protesters of protesters attended the vigil in the past. The vice-chairperson
of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China, Chow
Hang-tung, was arrested on Friday morning local time for allegedly promoting the banned
Tiananmen vigil. It is not immediately clear if demonstrators will turn out this year due to a
recent ban on gatherings. Avoid the area and expect associated disruptions in the vicinity.
Previous Updates:
Demonstrations across Hong Kong initially broke out in June 2019, originally called by the
Civil Human Rights Front (CHRF), in opposition to a proposed law allowing extraditions to
mainland China. While the extradition bill was withdrawn, the CHRF and its supporters
expanded their demands to include the release of detained protesters, the resignation of
Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam, an investigation into police responses to the
protests, universal suffrage for local elections, and retraction of the use of the word riot to
describe the protests. In 2020, demonstrators have also protested a national security law
for Hong Kong passed by the Chinese central government and a ban on insults to the
Chinese national anthem. Some demonstrations in 2019 saw participation levels as high as
several hundred thousand or more than one million; however, the size and frequency of
protests have declined this year due to the COVID-19 outbreak and greater government
restrictions on the protest movement. Individuals are advised to monitor developments
and to avoid any demonstrations due to the potential for clashes.
